claim: AI-driven biomedical science can shrink clinical development timelines to roughly a year for many interventions when effect sizes are large, and improved preclinical models/simulations can reduce iteration in human trials, enabling extensive parallelization.
explanation: Evidence does not support that AI can shrink clinical development to ~1 year for many interventions. Across 405 FDA approvals (2010–2020), median time from first‑in‑human to approval was 8.3 years; even with expedited pathways, oncology programs typically took ~4.5–6.7 years. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9869766/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) COVID‑19 vaccines reached EUA in ~10–11 months only under exceptional pandemic conditions with overlapping phases and at‑risk manufacturing, which is not generalizable. ([gao.gov](https://www.gao.gov/products/gao-21-319?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) As of 2025, no AI‑discovered drugs have been approved, so there’s no empirical basis that AI routinely compresses clinical development to ~1 year. ([wired.com](https://www.wired.com/story/artificial-intelligence-drug-discovery?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [ft.com](https://www.ft.com/content/b279d3d4-f1b5-4733-8e64-fcbf90d12219?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) However, improved models/simulations (MIDD, PBPK) can reduce iteration—often saving months and sometimes up to ~2 years—and master‑protocol/platform trials allow parallel evaluation, supporting the second half of the claim. ([ascpt.onlinelibrary.wiley.com](https://ascpt.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/cpt.2265?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/40135941/?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [fda.gov](https://www.fda.gov/about-fda/cder-offices-and-divisions/program-physiologically-based-pharmacokinetic-and-pharmacodynamic-modeling-pbpk-program?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [nejm.org](https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/nejmra1510062?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
